content:
The Act is titled the "Pro Football Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the Act. The Pro Football Hall of Fame's mission is to honor individuals who have made outstanding contributions to professional football, preserve historic documents and artifacts, educate the public about the sport's origin and promote its positive values. The Hall of Fame opened on September 7, 1963, enshrining a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors including legends like Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. The Pro Football Hall of Fame, established on September 7, 1963, honored a charter class of 17 players, coaches, and contributors including legends like Sammy Baugh, Red Grange, and Jim Thorpe. There are now 273 members in the Hall of Fame, each represented by a bronze bust, a gold jacket, and a ring. The museum has welcomed nearly 9 million visitors since opening, expanding from 19,000 to 118,000 square feet through various renovations. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has expanded its facility from 19,000 to 118,000 square feet through multiple renovations. The museum houses the world's largest collection on professional football, including over 20,000 artifacts and 20 million pages of documents. It reaches a global audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various events. The Pro Football Hall of Fame reaches a worldwide audience of nearly 15 million people annually through various events, including visitors to the museum, the Enshrinement Festival, televised events, the Hall of Fame's website, social media, special events, and educational outreach programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The half-dollar clad coins minted under this Act will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet the specifications for half-dollar coins in title 31, United States Code. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act will symbolize professional football, with specific inscriptions and values. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2016.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of design and issuance. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half-dollar coin. The surcharges will be promptly paid to the Pro Football Hall of Fame for construction and renovation. The Hall of Fame will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for the issuance of any coin under this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to ensure compliance with audit requirements under section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code. No surcharge can be included for issuing coins if it exceeds the annual limit of commemorative coin programs.
